article.paragraph: RefimproveApril 2013Politics of Central African RepublicThepolitics of theCentral African Republicformally take place in a framework of asemi-presidential systemsemi-presidentialrepublic. In this system, theHeads of state of the Central African Republic (and Central African Empire)Presidentis thehead of state, with aHeads of government of the Central African Republic (and Central African Empire)Prime Ministerashead of government.Executive poweris exercised by the government.Legislative poweris vested in both the government and parliament.

Changes in government have occurred in recent years by three methods: violence, negotiations, and elections. Both Bozize and Djotodia assumed the Presidency through takeover by violent means; however, elections were held in March 2005 and promised in 2013. A ceasefire agreement in January 2013 called for a multipartisan unity government.

The government was deposed in 15 March 2003 by forces under the rebel leaderFranois Boziz, who promised elections in 18 to 30 months. A new cabinet was set up in 1 April 2003. Elections were held on 13 March 2005.

On 11 January 2013, a ceasefire was signed by theSlkarebel coalition, which had aimed to bring down the government of President Boziz. According to this agreement, a new unity government would be formed. The President would appoint a new prime minister from the opposition parties, and theNational Assembly of the Central African Republicwould be dissolved and new legislative elections would be held within twelve months.Central African Republic ceasefire signed

However, two months later, the Slka rebels felt their terms were not being met, and at the culmination of the2012-2013 Central African Republic conflict, they attacked and took the capital,Bangui. The president, Boziz, fled to neighboringCameroonvia theDemocratic Republic of Congoon 24 March 2013.cite webhttp://edition.cnn.com/2013/03/24/world/africa/central-african-republic-unrest/index.htmlCentral African Republic president flees capital amid violence, official says24 Mar 201324 Mar 2013CNNcite newshttp://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/26/world/africa/leader-of-central-african-republic-francois-bozize-is-in-cameroon.htmlLeader of Central African Republic Fled to Cameroon, Official SaysLydia PolgreenThe New York Times25 March 2013

article.paragraph: Office-table|small[[Heads of state of the Central African Republic (and Central African Empire)|Acting President]]|small[[Catherine Samba-Panza]]|small[[Independent (politician)|Independent]]|small23 January 2014|-|small[[Heads of government of the Central African Republic (and Central African Empire)|Acting Prime Minister]]|small[[Mahamat Kamoun]]|small[[Independent (politician)|Independent]]|small10 August 2014|}The president is elected by popular vote for a six-year term, the prime minister is appointed by the president. The president also appoints and presides over theCentral African Republic Council of MinistersCouncil of Ministers, which initiates laws and oversees government operations.
article.heading: Legislative branch
article.paragraph: TheNational Assembly of the Central African RepublicNational Assembly(Assemble Nationale) has 105 members, elected for a five-year term using the two-round (orTwo-round systemRun-off) system.

article.heading: Judicial branch
article.paragraph: The Supreme Court, orCour Supreme, is made up of judges appointed by the president. There is also a Constitutional Court, and its judges are also appointed by the president.
article.heading: Administrative divisions
article.paragraph: The Central African Republic is divided in 14 prefectures (prefectures), 2 economic prefectures* (prefectures economiques), and 1 commune**; Bamingui-Bangoran, Bangui**, Basse-Kotto, Gribingui*, Haute-Kotto, Haute-Sangha, Haut-Mbomou,Kemo-Gribingui, Lobaye, Mbomou, Nana-Mambere, Ombella-Mpoko, Ouaka, Ouham, Ouham-Pende, Sangha*, Vakaga.
